client: Waddell Engineering Ltd., Blakestyle Design & Drafting Inc.
gravity_system: Pre-Engineered Trusses, Steel Beams, Concrete Piers, Continuous Footings
lateral_system: Knee Braces, Diagonal Bracing, Lateral Bracing
key_elements: Knee Braces, Snow Shadow, Roof Bracing, Concrete Piers
overall_building_description: The Werkema Barn Addition project involves a comprehensive integration of structural elements designed to support agricultural equipment storage. The structural framework is primarily composed of pre-engineered trusses, which are supported by W8x21 and W10x22 steel beams. These beams are strategically placed at 20-foot intervals to ensure optimal load distribution across the roof structure. The use of HSS 4"x4"x1/4" knee braces is critical for lateral stability, providing resistance against wind and seismic forces. The knee braces are connected to the beams using 2x6 or 2x8 plates secured with 1/2-inch bolts staggered at 24 inches on center, ensuring a robust connection that accommodates dynamic loads. The foundation system is meticulously designed with 16"x16"x48" concrete piers reinforced with (4) #4 vertical rebars and ties, resting on 48"x48"x24" concrete pad footings. These footings are embedded in a minimum of 6 inches of compacted granular 'A' fill, which provides a stable base and prevents settlement. The foundation plan emphasizes the importance of not undermining existing footings, with specific instructions for the installation of 18-inch epoxied dowels to enhance the connection between new and existing structures. The roof framing plan outlines the use of pre-engineered trusses, which are tied down as per the truss manufacturer's specifications, reviewed by the project engineer. The roof bracing notes highlight the necessity for diagonal bracing on all web members, with lateral and X-bracing provided at endwalls to maintain structural integrity. The truss supplier is tasked with designing the trusses to withstand specified loads, with any modifications requiring engineer approval. The elevation views incorporate snow shadow diagrams, indicating snow loads of 4.29 kPa and 1.53 kPa over a span of 22 feet, which are critical for assessing the roof's load-bearing capacity. The integration of these elements ensures a cohesive structural system capable of supporting the intended agricultural use while adhering to engineering standards and safety codes. The project requires detailed coordination between design and construction teams to ensure all components are fabricated and installed according to the specified guidelines, with particular attention to connection details, material specifications, and load path continuity. The use of stamped steel shop drawings for review by the project engineer underscores the emphasis on precision and compliance with design criteria. The assembly sequence involves careful alignment of new roof trusses with the existing building, necessitating adjustments to post and beam heights to achieve seamless integration. The project also considers environmental factors, such as snow loads, and incorporates design features to mitigate potential impacts, ensuring the longevity and functionality of the barn addition.
